<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 306, 220, 320]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 304, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 324, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 494, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 509, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 910, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 600, 724, 615]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 615, 593, 630]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 630, 606, 646]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 658, 608, 674]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 674, 756, 690]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 689, 440, 705]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A particle is projected with speed \(24 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) above the horizontal. Find the speed and direction of motion of the particle at the instant 4 s after projection. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The smallest cube is now removed from the object. It is replaced by a heavier uniform cube with \(1 \mathrm{~m}\) edges which is made of a different material. The centre of mass of the object is now at the base of the \(2 \mathrm{~m}\) cube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 135, 153, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 135, 616, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the ratio of the masses of the two cubes of edge 1 m.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A small ball is projected from a point \(O\) on horizontal ground. At time \(t\) s after projection the horizontal and vertically upwards displacements of the ball from \(O\) are \(x\) m and \(y\) m respectively, where \(x = 4t\) and \(y = 6t - 5t^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 138, 156, 155]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 136, 520, 155]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the trajectory of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 440, 186, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 440, 821, 459]]<|/det|>
Hence or otherwise calculate the angle of projection of the ball and its initial speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 459]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 87, 692, 207]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 221, 920, 272]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) is attached to a fixed point \(A\) by a light elastic string of natural length \(0.8 \mathrm{m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(16 \mathrm{N}\). The particle \(P\) moves in a horizontal circle which has centre \(O\). It is given that \(AO\) is vertical and that angle \(OAP\) is \(60^{\circ}\) (see diagram). Calculate the speed of \(P\). [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.3 \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to one end of a light elastic string of natural length \(0.6 \mathrm{~m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(24 \mathrm{~N}\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(O\). The particle \(P\) is released from rest at the point \(0.4 \mathrm{~m}\) vertically below \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 390, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the greatest speed of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 156, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 519, 91]]<|/det|>
Calculate the greatest distance of \(P\) below \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 44, 512, 61]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 81, 690, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 319, 544, 337]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 359, 920, 425]]<|/det|>
The prism has weight \(W\mathbf{N}\) and is placed with its curved surface on a rough horizontal plane. The axis of symmetry of the cross-section makes an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) with the vertical. A horizontal force of magnitude \(P\mathbf{N}\) acting in the plane of the cross-section through the centre of mass is applied to the cylinder at the highest point of this cross-section (see Fig. 2). The prism rests in limiting equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 438, 153, 456]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 438, 662, 456]]<|/det|>
Find the coefficient of friction between the prism and the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 438, 920, 456]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) is projected horizontally from a point \(O\) on a rough horizontal surface. The coefficient of friction between the particle and the surface is 0.2. A horizontal force of magnitude \(0.06t \mathrm{~N}\) directed away from \(O\) acts on \(P\), where \(t\) s is the time after projection. \(P\) comes to rest when \(t = 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 811, 154]]<|/det|>
The particle begins to move again when \(t = 8\). Show that the mass of \(P\) is \(0.24 \mathrm{~kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]
